curriculum.subject: Physical Education

subtopics.name: Skeletal System
keyPoints: Functions of the skeleton (protection, support, movement, mineral storage, blood cell production)
Types of bones (long, short, flat, irregular, sesamoid)
Bone structure (compact and spongy bone, periosteum, marrow)
Synovial joint types (hinge, ball and socket, pivot, gliding, saddle, condyloid)
Joint movement terminology (flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, rotation, circumduction)

definitions.articulation: A joint where two or more bones meet
definitions.synovialJoint: A freely movable joint containing synovial fluid
definitions.ligament: Connective tissue connecting bone to bone
definitions.cartilage: Smooth tissue covering bone ends at joints
definitions.flexion: Decreasing the angle at a joint
definitions.extension: Increasing the angle at a joint

exampleQuestions: Name and describe three functions of the skeletal system
Identify the type of synovial joint at the shoulder and knee
Explain the movements possible at a ball and socket joint
Describe the structure of a synovial joint

subtopics.name: Muscular System
keyPoints: Types of muscle tissue (skeletal, cardiac, smooth)
Muscle fiber types (Type I slow twitch, Type IIa fast oxidative, Type IIb fast glycolytic)
Types of muscle contraction (isotonic, isometric, isokinetic)

definitions.agonist: The prime mover muscle causing movement
definitions.slowTwitch: Type I fibers for endurance activities
definitions.fastTwitch: Type II fibers for power and speed

exampleQuestions: Compare and contrast Type I and Type II muscle fibers
Describe the sliding filament theory of muscle contraction
Identify the agonist and antagonist during a bicep curl
Explain the difference between concentric and eccentric contractions

subtopics.name: Cardiovascular System
keyPoints: Structure of the heart (chambers, valves, vessels)
Structure of blood vessels (arteries, veins, capillaries)
Blood composition (plasma, red blood cells, white blood cells, platelets)
Heart rate, stroke volume, cardiac output
Cardiovascular responses to exercise (acute and chronic)

definitions.heartRate: Number of heart beats per minute (bpm)
definitions.strokeVolume: Volume of blood pumped per beat (ml)
definitions.cardiacOutput: Volume of blood pumped per minute (HR x SV)
definitions.venousReturn: Blood returning to the heart via veins
definitions.arteriovenousOxygenDifference: Difference in O2 content between arterial and venous blood

exampleQuestions: Describe the pathway of blood through the heart
Calculate cardiac output given HR and SV
Explain cardiovascular adaptations to aerobic training
Describe acute cardiovascular responses to exercise

subtopics.name: Respiratory System
keyPoints: Structure of respiratory system (nose, pharynx, larynx, trachea, bronchi, lungs, alveoli)
Gaseous exchange at alveoli and muscles
Lung volumes and capacities (tidal volume, vital capacity, residual volume)
Respiratory responses to exercise (acute and chronic)

definitions.tidalVolume: Volume of air breathed in/out per breath
definitions.vitalCapacity: Maximum volume of air that can be exhaled after max inhalation
definitions.residualVolume: Air remaining in lungs after maximal exhalation
definitions.minuteVentilation: Volume of air breathed per minute (TV x RR)
definitions.inspiratoryReserveVolume: Additional air that can be inhaled after normal breath
definitions.expiratoryReserveVolume: Additional air that can be exhaled after normal breath
definitions.VO2max: Maximum oxygen uptake during maximal exercise
definitions.diffusion: Movement of gases from high to low concentration
definitions.alveoli: Air sacs where gas exchange occurs

exampleQuestions: Describe the process of gaseous exchange at the alveoli
Explain how breathing is controlled during exercise
Define VO2 max and its significance in performance
Outline respiratory adaptations to endurance training

subtopics.name: Energy Systems
keyPoints: Three energy systems (ATP-PC, Lactic Acid, Aerobic)
Aerobic system (Krebs cycle, electron transport chain)
Duration, intensity, and recovery for each system

definitions.ATP: Adenosine triphosphate - primary energy source for cells
definitions.phosphocreatine: High energy compound that regenerates ATP
definitions.OBLA: Point where lactate accumulates faster than removal
definitions.mitochondria: Powerhouse of cell where aerobic energy produced

exampleQuestions: Compare the three energy systems in terms of duration and intensity
Explain why the ATP-PC system is used in 100m sprint
Describe the process of aerobic energy production
Explain the concept of EPOC (oxygen debt)

subtopics.name: Principles of Training

definitions.specificity: Training must be relevant to the sport/activity
definitions.reversibility: Fitness gains are lost when training stops
definitions.periodization: Planned training phases to peak for competition

exampleQuestions: Explain the principle of progressive overload
Describe how specificity applies to a soccer player's training
Outline a periodized training plan for a swimmer
Explain the importance of variety in training programs

subtopics.name: Components of Fitness

definitions.cardiovascularEndurance: Ability of heart and lungs to supply oxygen during sustained activity
definitions.muscularStrength: Maximum force a muscle can generate in single effort
definitions.flexibility: Range of motion at a joint
definitions.bodyComposition: Ratio of fat mass to lean mass
definitions.coordination: Using different body parts together smoothly

exampleQuestions: Distinguish between health-related and skill-related fitness
Identify the main fitness components needed for basketball
Define muscular strength and muscular endurance
Explain the importance of flexibility in preventing injury

subtopics.name: Training Methods
keyPoints: Heart rate monitoring (maximum HR, target HR)

definitions.continuousTraining: Sustained aerobic activity at constant intensity
definitions.intervalTraining: Periods of work alternating with rest
definitions.plyometrics: Explosive jump training using stretch-shortening cycle
definitions.circuitTraining: Series of exercises at different stations
definitions.RPE: Subjective scale of exercise intensity (e.g., Borg scale)

exampleQuestions: Design an interval training session for a 400m runner
Compare continuous training with fartlek training
Explain the benefits of plyometric training for power athletes
Describe different flexibility training methods

subtopics.name: Fitness Testing
keyPoints: Cardiovascular endurance tests (Cooper 12-min, multistage fitness test/beep test, step test)
Muscular endurance tests (sit-up test, press-up test)
Power tests (vertical jump, standing long jump)

definitions.validity: Test measures what it claims to measure
definitions.1RM: One repetition maximum - heaviest weight lifted once
definitions.beepTest: Multistage fitness test with progressive speeds
definitions.sitAndReach: Flexibility test for hamstrings and lower back

exampleQuestions: Explain the importance of validity and reliability in fitness testing
Describe how to conduct the multistage fitness test
Outline appropriate fitness tests for a rugby player
Discuss advantages and disadvantages of BMI as a measure

subtopics.name: Classification of Skills
keyPoints: High organization vs low organization skills

definitions.openSkill: Performed in unpredictable environment (e.g., passing in soccer)
definitions.closedSkill: Performed in predictable environment (e.g., free throw)
definitions.discreteSkill: Clear beginning and end (e.g., penalty kick)
definitions.serialSkill: Series of discrete skills linked together (e.g., gymnastics routine)
definitions.continuousSkill: No clear beginning or end (e.g., swimming)

exampleQuestions: Classify a tennis serve using different skill classifications
Explain the difference between open and closed skills with examples
Discuss why a gymnastics floor routine is a serial skill

subtopics.name: Information Processing
keyPoints: Knowledge of results (KR) and knowledge of performance (KP)
Reaction time, movement time, response time

definitions.responseProgramming: Organizing motor system to execute movement
definitions.extrinsicFeedback: External feedback from coach or video
definitions.reactionTime: Time from stimulus to start of movement

exampleQuestions: Describe the information processing model
Explain the difference between KR and KP with examples
Discuss factors that affect reaction time in sprint starts
Outline how anticipation can improve performance

subtopics.name: Learning Theories and Stages

definitions.cognitiveStage: Beginner stage, many errors, intellectual understanding
definitions.associativeStage: Practice stage, fewer errors, motor programs developing
definitions.positiveReinforcement: Adding pleasant stimulus to encourage behavior
definitions.negativeReinforcement: Removing unpleasant stimulus to encourage behavior

exampleQuestions: Describe the three stages of learning according to Fitts and Posner
Explain how positive reinforcement can improve skill learning
Discuss when part practice is more effective than whole practice
Outline the characteristics of a performer in the autonomous stage

subtopics.name: Guidance and Teaching Styles
keyPoints: Appropriate teaching styles for different learners
exampleQuestions: Discuss advantages and disadvantages of manual guidance
Explain when verbal guidance is most effective
Compare command and discovery teaching styles
Describe appropriate guidance for teaching swimming to beginners

subtopics.name: Motivation and Goal Setting
keyPoints: SMART goals (Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound)

definitions.achievementMotivation: Desire to succeed and master skills
definitions.selfEfficacy: Belief in one's ability to succeed

exampleQuestions: Explain the difference between intrinsic and extrinsic motivation
Describe how SMART goals can improve performance
Discuss the importance of process goals for athletes
Outline how self-efficacy affects performance

subtopics.name: Arousal, Anxiety and Stress

definitions.invertedU: Theory that moderate arousal optimizes performance

exampleQuestions: Explain the inverted-U hypothesis with examples
Describe strategies to control anxiety before competition
Discuss the difference between arousal and anxiety
Outline how imagery can improve performance

theoreticalComponents.title: Sociology of Sport and Physical Activity

subtopics.name: Sport and Society

definitions.socialization: Learning values and norms through sport
definitions.commercialization: Sport driven by profit and business
definitions.sponsorship: Financial support in exchange for promotion
definitions.mediaRights: Broadcasting rights sold to media companies

exampleQuestions: Discuss the role of sport in promoting national identity
Explain how media has influenced modern sport
Analyze the commercialization of the Olympic Games
Outline positive and negative effects of sponsorship in sport

subtopics.name: Participation and Access

definitions.inclusion: Ensuring all can participate regardless of ability
definitions.genderEquality: Equal opportunities and treatment for all genders
definitions.socioeconomicStatus: Social and economic position affecting access

exampleQuestions: Identify barriers to sport participation for people with disabilities
Discuss how gender affects participation in sport
Explain initiatives to increase youth participation in physical activity
Analyze socioeconomic barriers to sport participation

subtopics.name: Ethics and Fair Play

definitions.sportsmanship: Fair, ethical, respectful behavior in sport
definitions.fairPlay: Following rules and spirit of the game
definitions.deviance: Behavior that violates norms and rules
definitions.doping: Using banned substances to enhance performance

exampleQuestions: Distinguish between sportsmanship and gamesmanship
Discuss reasons why athletes use performance-enhancing drugs
Explain the role of WADA in preventing doping
Analyze the responsibilities of athletes as role models

subtopics.name: Health and Well-being

definitions.physicalHealth: Well-being of body and physiological systems
definitions.socialWellbeing: Quality of relationships and social interactions
definitions.sedentary: Inactive lifestyle with little physical activity
definitions.nutrition: Food intake to support health and performance

exampleQuestions: Outline physical and mental health benefits of regular activity
Discuss consequences of sedentary lifestyle
Explain the importance of nutrition for athletic performance
Describe strategies for injury prevention in sport

practicalComponents.description: Students must perform in FOUR different activities from different categories

assessmentCriteria.application: Use of skills in competitive/performance context

performanceAnalysis.description: Written analysis of own performance in one activity
components: Apply theoretical knowledge to practical performance

cards.front: What are the 5 functions of the skeletal system?
cards.back:
1. Protection (of organs)
2. Support (for body structure)
3. Movement (with muscles)
4. Mineral storage (calcium, phosphorus)
5. Blood cell production (in bone marrow)

cards.front: What type of joint is the shoulder?
cards.back: Ball and socket joint - allows movement in all directions (flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, rotation, circumduction)
Decreasing the angle at a joint (e.g., bending the elbow)
Connective tissue that connects bone to bone and provides joint stability

1. Long bones (femur, humerus)
2. Short bones (carpals, tarsals)
3. Flat bones (scapula, ribs)

cards.front: Compare Type I and Type II muscle fibers
cards.back:
Type I (Slow Twitch): Aerobic, fatigue resistant, endurance activities
Type II (Fast Twitch): Anaerobic, fatigue quickly, power and speed activities

cards.front: What is the difference between concentric and eccentric contractions?
cards.back:
Concentric: Muscle shortens during contraction (lifting phase)
Eccentric: Muscle lengthens during contraction (lowering phase)

Agonist: Prime mover muscle causing the movement
Antagonist: Muscle that opposes the agonist (relaxes)
Muscle contracts but does not change length - no visible movement (e.g., holding a plank position)

Volume of blood pumped by the heart per minute
Cardiac Output = Heart Rate x Stroke Volume
The volume of blood pumped out of the left ventricle per beat (measured in ml)

cards.front: Describe the pathway of blood through the heart
cards.back: Vena Cava → Right Atrium → Right Ventricle → Pulmonary Artery → Lungs → Pulmonary Vein → Left Atrium → Left Ventricle → Aorta → Body

cards.front: What is the difference between systole and diastole?
cards.back:
Systole: Contraction phase of the cardiac cycle
Diastole: Relaxation phase of the cardiac cycle
The maximum volume of oxygen that can be taken in and used by the body during maximal exercise (measured in ml/kg/min)
The volume of air breathed in or out per breath during normal breathing (approximately 500ml at rest)

cards.front: Describe gaseous exchange at the alveoli
cards.back: Oxygen diffuses from high concentration in alveoli to low concentration in blood capillaries. CO2 diffuses from high concentration in blood to low concentration in alveoli

Volume of air breathed per minute
Minute Ventilation = Tidal Volume x Respiratory Rate

1. ATP-PC (Phosphocreatine) System
2. Lactic Acid System (Anaerobic Glycolysis)
3. Aerobic System

Duration: 0-10 seconds
Anaerobic, no lactic acid
Used for: explosive, high-intensity activities (100m sprint, shot put)
Fuel: Phosphocreatine
Onset of Blood Lactate Accumulation - the point during exercise where lactate accumulates faster than it can be removed from the blood
Excess Post-exercise Oxygen Consumption - elevated oxygen consumption after exercise to restore body to resting state (also called oxygen debt)

cards.front: What is the principle of specificity?
cards.back: Training must be specific to the sport, movement patterns, energy systems, and muscle groups used in that activity
Gradually increasing the training load (intensity, duration, frequency) to improve fitness over time
Fitness gains are lost when training stops or decreases (use it or lose it principle)

Frequency: How often you train
Intensity: How hard you train
Time: Duration of training
Type: Kind of training/activity
A skill performed in an unpredictable, changing environment where performer must adapt (e.g., passing in soccer)
A skill performed in a stable, predictable environment (e.g., free throw in basketball, penalty kick)

cards.front: Name Fitts and Posner's 3 stages of learning
cards.back:
1. Cognitive Stage (beginner)
2. Associative Stage (practice)
3. Autonomous Stage (advanced/automatic)
External feedback about the outcome of a movement (e.g., whether a shot went in or not)
External feedback about the quality and execution of the movement technique
Performance improves with increased arousal up to an optimal point, then decreases with further arousal increases. Moderate arousal = best performance
Internal drive to participate for enjoyment, satisfaction, and personal achievement (no external rewards needed)
Drive to participate for external rewards such as trophies, money, praise, or recognition

Specific
Measurable
Achievable
Relevant
Time-bound

questions.question: Which type of joint is the knee?
questions.explanation: The knee is a hinge joint allowing flexion and extension

questions.question: What connects muscle to bone?
questions.explanation: Tendons attach muscle to bone, while ligaments connect bone to bone

questions.question: Which chamber of the heart pumps oxygenated blood to the body?
questions.explanation: The left ventricle pumps oxygenated blood through the aorta to the body

questions.question: What is the primary muscle used in breathing?
questions.explanation: The diaphragm is the main respiratory muscle that contracts during inspiration

questions.question: Which energy system is primarily used in a 100m sprint?
questions.explanation: The ATP-PC system provides immediate energy for explosive activities lasting 0-10 seconds

questions.question: What does cardiovascular endurance refer to?
questions.explanation: Cardiovascular endurance is the ability of the heart and lungs to supply oxygen during sustained physical activity

questions.question: Which is NOT a principle of training?
questions.explanation: The main principles of training are specificity, progressive overload, reversibility, tedium, and individual differences

questions.question: An athlete in the autonomous stage of learning would display:
questions.explanation: The autonomous stage is characterized by automatic, smooth, and consistent performance with minimal errors

questions.question: What is positive reinforcement?
questions.explanation: Positive reinforcement involves adding a pleasant stimulus (praise, reward) to encourage desired behavior

questions.question: What is gamesmanship?
questions.explanation: Gamesmanship involves bending rules and using dubious tactics to gain an advantage without technically breaking rules

questions.question: Which organization monitors anti-doping in sport?
questions.explanation: WADA (World Anti-Doping Agency) is responsible for monitoring and enforcing anti-doping regulations worldwide

diagrams: Upper limb bones (clavicle, scapula, humerus, radius, ulna, carpals, metacarpals, phalanges)
Lower limb bones (pelvis, femur, patella, tibia, fibula, tarsals, metatarsals, phalanges)
Major muscles (anterior view): pectorals, deltoids, biceps, abdominals, quadriceps, tibialis anterior
Major muscles (posterior view): trapezius, latissimus dorsi, triceps, gluteals, hamstrings, gastrocnemius

phases.example: 30-40 min runs at 60-70% max HR, 3-4 times per week
Fartlek sessions, tempo runs, 40-50 min duration

phases.focus: High intensity intervals, race pace work
phases.example: HIIT sessions, 30-40 min at 75-85% max HR

examTips: Answer all questions - no choice in Section A
Read questions carefully - note command words (describe, explain, discuss, outline)
Draw and label diagrams where appropriate
Manage time - don't spend too long on one question
Section B extended responses need structure and depth
Link theory to practical examples from your activities
Understand differences between Higher and Ordinary level expectations
